text: What is I want in French, I want?
Je veux.
He wants.
Il veut.
She wants.
Elle veut.
You, informal want.
Tu veux.
One wants.
On veut.
How would you say one wants to leave?
On veut partir.
Now that does sound unusual in English, to say one wants to leave.
It's perhaps the sort of thing you might possibly expect to hear from royalty.
It certainly sounds unusual.
But in French, certainly less so.
Because in addition to the most important rule, which is,
if you could use one in English, you must use it in French,
it also has some more broad uses than even in English,
even where we could use it.
It is possible in French to use one more or less as a replacement for we.
So, where we might use we normally in English,
in French of course, you can use the French word for we,
but you can also frequently use one.
And you'll find that the French very, very often do this.
It's not considered at all unusual to use this form of expression in French.
And in fact, it's quite normal.
It doesn't carry any particular posh feeling or unusual feeling.
But you don't need to feel that you have to do it when you're speaking French.
If you want, you can simply stick to we.
But it is important to be aware that French native speakers will speak in this way sometimes.
And so it's important to begin to get to grips with it
and the variety of meanings that one can have in French.
So again, what is I want?
Je veux.
He wants.
Il veut.
She wants.
Elle veut.
One wants.
On veut.
What about you, formal want?
Vous voulez.
We want.
Nous voulons.
They want.
Ils veulent.
Again, if you struggle to remember the they form,
the first thing to do is to go back to he wants,
which is of course...
Il veut.
And then to add an additional consonant sound to the end,
which you can find in the middle of voulait.
So it's the L from voulait,
we're adding that sound onto the end.
So again, how would you say they want?
Ils veulent.
How would you say they want to leave?
Ils veulent partir.
How would you say they want to go there?
Ils veulent y aller.
They want to go there later.
Ils veulent y aller plus tard.
They want to go there today.
Ils veulent y aller aujourd'hui.
They, an entirely female group, want to go there now.
They want to go there.
They want to go there.
They want to go there.
They want to go there.
They want to go there this evening.
They want to go there this evening.
They want to go there this evening.
They want to go there.
They want to go there.
They want to go there.
How would you say in French,
can you recommend me a restaurant because I want to eat now?
The word for because in French, if you've forgotten, is
parce que.
So again, can you recommend me a restaurant because I want to eat now?
Pouvez-vous me recommander un restaurant parce que je veux manger maintenant?
How would you say in French, I have a room?
J'ai une chambre.
How would you say, I have a room for two people for two nights?
J'ai une chambre pour deux personnes pour deux nuits.
How would you add that it has a shower and say, with shower?
With douche.
Or perhaps it comes with breakfast.
How would you say with breakfast?
Avec petit déjeuner.
How would you say, can you recommend me a hotel?
Pouvez-vous me recommander un hôtel?
Hotel in French is pronounced hotel.
Because the H is never clearly pronounced in French.
How would you say, I would like a room for two people for two nights with breakfast.
Can you recommend me a hotel?
Let's break that down into some smaller parts first.
Start by saying, I would like a room for two people for two nights.
I would like a room for two people for two nights.
With breakfast.
With breakfast.
With breakfast.
Can you recommend me a hotel?
Of course, another way if you're looking for a hotel is simply to say, where is the hotel?
How would you say that?
Again, in the same way that the word le tends to abbreviate with vowels, because the H in French is more or less silent, it also abbreviates.
So, the hotel becomes...
Again, don't worry too much if you think a new word has been invented called a l'hotel.
It's not.
It's simply two words abbreviated together.
Again, how would you say, where is the car park?
Où est le parking?
And where is the campsite?
Où est le camping?
How would you say the campsite is over there?
Le camping est là-bas.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Thank you.
